text: it's Father's Day
again and I'm making my dad a chocolate
cake today I'm making something a little
more elaborate
it's a blackberry forest cake to start
off you want to whisk together your dry
ingredients
I have 2/3 of a cup of cake flour in
this bowl it's already sifted and to
that add 1/3 of a cup of unsweetened
Dutch processed cocoa powder everything
needs to be sifted because you're making
a genoise that's made with beaten eggs
so you want everything really fine don't
risk having any lumps then add a half a
teaspoon of salt and whisk that together
then what you want to do to start off
this cake is whisk your sugar and eggs
together until they're warm so here I
have 2/3 of a cup of sugar this is a pot
of simmering water and then add four
whole eggs plus three egg yolks to your
sugar and then you want to whisk
everything until the sugar dissolves and
the egg mixture is warm this will allow
the mixture to get really light and
fluffy once you put it on to the mixer
and start whisking the warm and the eggs
are the more volume you're going to get
but you have to be very careful when
it's sitting on top of hot water that
the eggs don't begin to cook on the
sides of the pot so keep whisking you
want to whisk and whisk until your sugar
is dissolved and the mixture is hot and
honestly the only way that you can tell
if that's happened is by sticking your
finger in it and then your fingers all
sticking but there's really no way
around it
good enough off then transfer everything
to your mixer you can do this with a
handheld but it'll take quite a bit
longer you really need to get a lot of
volume here all the leavening is coming
from the egg so you want to make sure
that it gets nice and light and fluffy
it'll like double in volume you'll see
what I mean
it's palin thick now which is what
you're looking for it takes about two
minutes on medium and then about four
minutes on high and then you can fold
your dry ingredients in you want to sift
the dry ingredients over the top of the
bowl this is the many times sifted but
well it has egg yolks in it so it's not
nearly that light it's the light now you
want to fold it almost but not
completely in because you have to add
some butter to this mixture so make sure
you have your butter on hand it's five
tablespoons of melted butter take about
one cup of the cake batter and sort of
fold / stir it into the butter you need
to get the butter incorporated into the
cake batter and this is a great way of
doing it without losing too much volume
then it can go back in and then fold
that in and that's your cake batter have
your oven preheating to 400 degrees and
then have two parchment lined buttered
and floured 9 by 2 inch cake pans divide
the batter evenly between the pans and
then get them into the oven they need to
bake until they're springy to the touch
and they just start pulling away from
the sides of the pans believe it or not
that'll only take about 10 or 11 minutes
okay so these have cooled I took them
out of the pan let them cool on racks
top side up to some of the cake you need
a couple things the first of which is a
ganache I have six ounces of chocolate
that I've chopped and three quarters of
a cup of heavy cream that is just now
coming to a simmer for your hot cream
right over the chocolate ganache is
really just a very fancy word for melted
chocolate and cream now you know to this
we're also going to add one tablespoon
of corn syrup that makes it just a
little bit shinier when it sets which is
what you want because this is going to
be a beautiful glaze on top of your cake
let it sit there for five minutes for
the chocolate to melt and then you whisk
it together to get the berries nice and
glazy
you're going to mix them with some jelly
this is a third of a cup of black
currant jelly but you can use blackberry
any kind of dark
a jelly you want with just a little bit
of lemon juice about a teaspoon whisk it
until it loosens this is four cups of
blackberries black forest cake is
normally made with cherries and you
could definitely use that it's certainly
seasonal just replace the blackberries
with sweet cherries pitted gently
actually to coat your berries in the
jelly mixture and you can see that they
get nice and shiny and then one last
thing was I made a simple syrup to brush
over my cakes this is made with third of
a cup of creme de cassis you could use
Kirsch if you wanted a third of a cup of
sugar and three tablespoons of water
again I should be ready to stir once the
chocolate has been sitting in the hot
cream it should come together really
nicely into a glaze listen there's a few
components to this cake which makes it a
little bit more complex but it also
makes it more special so that's why it's
great for a special occasion like
Father's Day to say how much you love
your dad you want to brush your cakes
really generously with the syrup Hamas
has a tendency to be just a little bit
dry which allows it to absorb the syrup
if you're not nice and generous with
your syrup your cake can come out a
little bit dry and you don't want that
I'm doing one topside up in one bottom
side up the recipes usually say brush
but I like to call this soaking and that
way people have a better idea of what I
mean when I say really saturate the cake
and I like to go so far as to do the
sides of the cake as well and if you
want to the layer that's going to be on
the top you can brush the bottom and the
top the one that's on the bottom you
really can't otherwise it will stick to
your cake stand I'm going to do a layer
of ganache on the bottom layer as well
as over the top so put some ganache on
the bottom spread it out so it goes all
the way to the edges and if a little bit
drips down the sides no problem then use
about three cups of your berries to
cover the top of your cake you want to
save about a cup to garnish the top with
so don't use them all up and even if
you're making this today for tomorrow
which is totally fantastic these berries
will be great tomorrow so you can mix
everything all together today and then
top off your cake when you're ready to
serve it get your cake fully covered
with a layer of berries these are black
berries which are really big so a single
layer of berries is plenty to cover this
cake now some whipped cream this is 3/4
of a cup of cream whipped with three
tablespoons of confectioner's sugar so
just a very lightly sweetened whipped
cream now you want to get this over all
those berries so if you want to kind of
stiff enough to hold its shape but not
too much
spread your cream over the top then top
with your top cake layer and then pour
the remaining ganache over the top this
is a make-ahead situation because this
needs to sit in the refrigerator for
about 4 hours and up to overnight it in
fact gets better as it sits so feel free
to make it ahead spread the ganache over
the top and this time you definitely
want it dripping down the side so let it
drip down the sides and get a nice
covering of ganache if your ganache has
set up a little bit while you're making
your cake you can just throw it in the
microwave for a few seconds to loosen it
up you want to make sure that it spreads
and sort of drips nicely down the sides
of the cake get this in the fridge for
about 4 hours and up to overnight 4
hours later or overnight ready to serve
spoon the remaining berries on top it's
about a cup and like I said any berries
would work here beautiful and ready to
serve I don't know I don't even want to
cut into it it's so beautiful
oh sweet a delicious berry and say happy
Father's Day dad I love you
you
